Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They notice a few swimmers occasionally drifting toward deeper water but no immediate danger arises.
Story: I sat on the edge of the pool, whistle around my neck, eyes scanning the water. My stepmom’s voice echoed from the picnic tables behind me, calling everyone for the family holiday toast. It was one of those traditions she insisted I join, a way to show I was really part of the family. I could see her watching, waiting for me to come over and raise my glass with everyone else. But my job as a lifeguard demanded I stay alert, eyes on the swimmers. A couple of kids were drifting toward the deep end, nothing urgent, but I knew how quickly things could change. My stepmom’s expectation pressed on me—I could almost feel her disappointment if I didn’t join. At the same time, the weight of responsibility as a lifeguard kept me rooted to my chair. I felt torn, heart pounding, caught between being the stepchild who wanted to belong and the lifeguard who couldn’t look away.
